title: The Bachelor's Abbie Chatfield says she was blindsided by her 'villain edit'
text:
Abbie Chatfield was labelled the 'villain' during this year's season of The Bachelor.

But the 24-year-old property analyst has defended herself in a passionate essay, saying she was unfairly portrayed as the show's antagonist.

In an article for Whimn, she said her fellow contestants misinterpreted her loud, playful and sexually forward personality.

'I never did anything mean': The Bachelor's Abbie Chatfield has revealed she was blindsided by her 'villain edit'

'I never did anything mean to any of the women, beyond spilling the beans on the "dog c***t" saga. I never spoke of any other woman to Matt [Agnew], I never said anything insulting to any of the women and I certainly didn't make any of them feel the way that I felt. Yet somehow, I was the villain,' she wrote.

Abbie said some of the women made her feel unwelcome in the mansion, and she found herself feeling paranoid and crying almost every day.

She added that having her heart broken in the finale (Matt chose Chelsie McLeod as his winner, leaving Abbie in second place) was made worse by the bullying she faced on social media.

Emotional journey: The 24-year-old property analyst defended herself in a passionate essay, saying she was unfairly portrayed as the show's antagonist

Abbie endured months of harassment on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram from strangers who shamed her for how she behaved on screen.

'It is extremely disheartening and concerning to see the eager willingness of the Australian public to jump on this bandwagon,' she wrote.

In a final message to reality TV fans, Abbie concluded: 'Analyse your opinions, consider if your message or comment will add or take [away] from the recipient's day and finally, please, just be kind.'

Her say: 'I never did anything mean to any of the women,' Abbie wrote in an article for Whimn

It's not the first time Abbie has taken aim at her online trolls.

In a recent Instagram post, she complained about being 'sl*t shamed' for the clothes she wore on The Bachelor as well as her steamy dates with Matt Agnew.

She wrote: 'This is something I did not expect in 2019. Sex is essential to a successful relationship for me, as is sexual chemistry and the ability to express that comfortably with my partner.'
